did.abstract: The Sid Gilman collection consists of biographical, UM departmental, research, and grant information, in addition to numerous lectures and presentations that Gilman has given during his tenure at both Columbia University and the University of Michigan. Correspondence, filmstrips, photographs, videotape, and other media are distributed throughout the collection. Material about Derek Denny-Brown is also included.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: Donated in March and December of 2004 (Donor no. 9466)

accessrestrict.p: The record group is open without restriction with the exception of one folder restricted and removed.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Sid Gilman papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Sid Gilman served as professor and chair of the University of Michigan Department of Neurology from 1977 to 2003 and was inaugurated as the first William J. Herdman Professor of Neurology in 1997. He received his undergraduate and medical degrees from the University of California at Los Angeles, graduating with the M.D. in 1957. After serving a year-long internship at the UCLA hospital, Gilman served as Research Associate at the National Institutes of Health for two years, then as Resident in Neurology at Harvard Medical School/Boston City Hospital Neurological Unit for three years. For the next two years, he was a research fellow, then a faculty member (first as an instructor, then as an associate) at Harvard Medical School/Boston City Hospital. In 1968, he left Harvard for Columbia University, where he joined as an Assistant Professor before becoming an Associate Professor, then Professor. He became the H. Houston Merit Professor of Neurology in 1976. The following year, he left Columbia for the University of Michigan.

Dr. Gilman received numerous awards and honors during his career. In addition to being a member of Phi Beta Kappa and Alpha Omega Alpha, he was the recipient of the Lucy G. Moses Prize in Basic Neurology, the UCLA Alumni Professional Achievement Award, and the UCLA Medical Alumni Professional Achievement Award. He belonged to several organizations, including the American Neurological Association and the Michigan Neurological Association, and served as President of both organizations. He is the author of over 300 journal articles and book chapters and wrote and edited six books. In addition, he served as Editor-in-Chief of the Contemporary Neurology Series, MedLink Neurology, and Experimental Neurology. He was a member of the editorial board of six other neurological journals. His work concerns neurodegenerative diseases, including Parkinson's and Alzheimer's, and cerebellar degenerations, modern approaches to imaging the nervous system, and the neurophysiological and neuropharmacological aspects of cerebellar and basal ganglia function.

scopecontent.p: The Sid Gilman collection consists primarily of correspondence and research papers detailing his professional career, although photographs, filmstrips, slides, and other images are also distributed throughout the collection. This collection is divided into seven series: Biographical Info, Professional Info, UM Neurology Department Info, Decade of the Brain, Lectures/Presentations, Denny-Brown Material and, Research. Two of these series are further divided into two sub-series. Parts of the collection are arranged in alphabetical order for ease of use, although the remaining series have been maintained in their original order. In addition, some of the contents are partially arranged in reverse chronological order, also as maintained originally.

controlaccess.head: Subjects:
controlaccess.corpname: University of Michigan--Dept. of Neurology.Dept. of Neurology.

scopecontent.p: Biographical Info (0.5 feet) contains tributes, honors, and awards that Gilman received throughout his career as a faculty member of the UM Neurology department. Notable honors include the Henry Russel award, and a tribute given in 2003. A videotape of the tribute is also included.

The Professional Info series (approx. 1 box total) consists of correspondence between Gilman and members of the various organizations and committees of which he was a part. There may also be some correspondence between members other than Gilman. The bulk of the files relate to the American Neurological association (ANA), but other organizations include the American Medical Association, the American Academy of Neurology (AAN), and the National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke (NINDS). The material in the Decade of the Brain series is related to Professional Info in that there is much correspondence between members of the AAN.

did.unittitle: ANA/Council of Academic Societies (CAS; part of Association of American Medical Colleges)
Health Care Issues Committee, ANA Council
National Advisory Council and Board Representatives Meeting
National Advisory of Neurological Disorders and Stroke (NANDS), Financial Disclosure
Peripheral and Central Nervous System Drugs Advisory Committee
Office of Government Ethics and Financial Disclosure Reports
University of Michigan Department of Neurology

scopecontent.p: The UM Departmental series (approx. 1 1/2 boxes) is divided into two sub-series. The Neurology Department info sub-series contains the history of and information about the department. There are also internal and external departmental reviews, annual reports, meeting minutes, and committee information. In addition, there are also several photographs of faculty members and residents. The bulk of the Grant Info sub-series consists of grant applications and Markey Grant annual progress reports (the Markey Grant being awarded through the Markey Charitable Trust, a limited term trust which was established to fund research grants to scientists, M.D.s, and Ph.Ds in the field of biomedical research).

did.unittitle: Grant Proposal, Disorders of Cerebral Biochemistry and Alcoholism
Markey Charitable Trust: Markey Grant Annual Progress Reports
Training in Clinical and Basic Neuroscience (grant application)
Dept. of Neurology Long Range Planning Committee
Faculty Curriculum Vitae, Bios, and Obituaries
NIMH Diagnostic Interview Schedule w/Intake Face Sheet

scopecontent.p: The Decade of the Brain series (1 box) largely consists of correspondence relating to the project of the same name, including, but not limited to, funding, the AAN Geriatrics Committee, minutes, and Decade of the Brain Steering Committee info. The Decade of the Brain was a project (?) that declared the years 1990-2000 as a time to focus on diseases and disorders of the brain.

did.unittitle: Agenda, Minutes, DoB Task Force, DoB Project Update
National Advisory Mental Health Council Report to Congress on the Decade of the Brain

scopecontent.p: The Lectures/Presentations (1 box) series comprises materials from the various national and international lectures, workshops, symposiums, and conferences that Gilman attended. This series also includes Grand Rounds (both correspondence and actual case studies).

did.unittitle: 1st International Brainstorming Conference on Progressive Supranuclear Palsy (PSP)
XV International Symposium on Cerebral Blood Flow and Metabolism
Health Insurance Association America (HIAA)-The Clinical Approach of PET
Intraspinal Transplantation and Clinical Application: Theoretical "Bench to Bedside" Transition (University of Florida)
Mechanisms for the Recovery of Function After Chronic Injury to the Nervous System workshop
Molecular Basis of Therapy in Neurology (contains slides)
PET Imaging Studies in Progressive Dementia
The Cerebellum in Health and Disease (Tubingen, Germany)
The Cerebellum in Motor Control: Current Controversies (Tubingen)

scopecontent.p: The Denny-Brown series (1 box) is a unique part of this collection in that it does not contain materials directly attributed to Gilman, nor does it focus on the works of Denny-Brown himself, who was a mentor to Gilman. Gilman later served as executor of Denny-Brown's estate. This series provides background on a larger collection of materials related to Denny-Brown that were previously held by the Bentley before being transferred to the National Museum of Medicine in Washington, D.C. The materials included in the Gilman collection consist largely of material about Denny-Brown complied by Gilman and contain video annotations of films done by Denny-Brown, information on the acquisition of Denny-Brown's materials, and miscellaneous correspondence.

The Research series (3 boxes) is further divided into two sub-series. The first, Positron Emission Tomography (PET), consists of one box of materials dealing with the history and implementation of PET, program project site visits, grant, budget, and account info, and information regarding the Michigan Alzheimer's Disease Research Center (MADRC). The second sub-series (2 boxes) contains several of Gilman's individual research papers, as well as correspondence related to the publishing of his work. Some papers may have more than one draft. These are the oldest materials in the collection, with dates ranging from 1961 to 1977, although the dates of some materials are unknown. Only a small sample of Gilman's research is included, but the material here is indicative of his methodology and interests.
